I used this term in preference to either sub- or counterculture for two reasons: first, it’s murkier, hence more suggestive; and second, it allowed me to shed some of the essentialism on class that tends to inhere in those latter terms and the distinction between them. In the end that underground scene, in London at least, was no more ‘anti-style’ or straightforwardly utopian than London punk in 1976 was all about ‘resistance’ and nothing else. Just as the 60s counter culture was intensely combative – countering not just the fundamental tenets of the control culture against which it defined itself, materialism, the work ethic, individualism, etc. – but in a sense, the very concept of culture per se as unconscious coercion to the norm, so punk contained, along with and within the nihilism that propelled it, a pronounced ethical component. 70s punk as a prophetic End-time discourse always involved an ethically based critique of and resistance to late capitalist, easy credit, spend-and-burn disposability and waste. It staked its claim in the dirty, unwanted and unwashed remainder of bourgeois post-hippy utopianism – in everything the organic movement defined itself against – in plastic, toxic gunk and industrial detritus. Rather than burying that remainder out of sight and out of mind, it stuck its face in it, then stuck its face into ours.

So once they’re seen as modalities of action rather than as objects, texts or styles, the punk vs. hippy distinction begins to blur and the terms begin to merge and hybridize, as they did in Austin, Texas when the so-called redneck-hippies led the ‘Outlaw Country’ charge against the country music establishment in Nashville in the early to mid-1970s. Certainly in the high desert communities in south-eastern California where I spend a lot of my time, it would be hard to draw a line between utopianism, resistance and survivalism when considering what it is that binds together in their isolation and their interlocking porous cliques the growing numbers of punks, hippies, Burning Man afficionados, boulderers, eco-warriors, off-gridders, off-roaders, tweakers, military personnel, retirees, religious secessionists, communards, experimental architects, artists, musicians, welfare recipients and ageing intellectuals who are gathering there.9

speech.speaker: Esther Leslie:
speech.p: Subculture: The Meaning of Style set much store by the concept of bricolage. It was itself a bricolage of theories: Marx, Kristeva, Williams, Gramsci, Barthes and so on. That bricoleuring is, of course, an aspect of the style. Was it the only way of proceeding? Was it necessary to draw all these quite contradictory sources in order to break with some other blanket mode of analysing? How consciously was such collaging evoked as an element of style? What were its specific effects and defects? Was there any sense at the time that this was a type of detourning, as Debord had undertaken in Society of the Spectacle, citing without necessarily giving a source bits of theory from here and there (although their intellectual provenance was more coherent than that in Subculture)? But if it was a deployment and also a detournement, was there any effect gained from the uprooting of theory splinters from one place to another – or did it only rearrange things: just as ‘Cut-ups and collages, no matter how bizarre, do not change as much as rearrange things’. Would the same names be thrown into the mix today in any rewriting of the book, or have those fragments’ power, even just to rearrange things, waned over time?

speech.speaker: Ina Blom:
speech.p: In your work on the meaning of subcultural style, you point out the similarities between the chaotic or obtuse uses of cultural signifiers by subcultural groups and the strategies of avant-garde works of art. However, you also draw a sharp line between these two phenomena: the subcultural appropriation of cultural codes should be seen as a purely contextual intervention in dominant culture, not to be confused with the timelessness and autonomy of works of art. Given the widespread theorization during the last 30 years or so of the avant-garde artwork as contextual, interventionist and event-oriented, would you still uphold this distinction today?

speech.speaker: Beatriz Preciado:
speech.p: I am particularly interested in transgender cultures and the use of body technologies as ways of resisting gender norms. Reading your groundbreaking book more than 30 years after its publication, its opening paragraphs dedicated to Genet’s Vaseline tube remain some of most bold and insightful pages of cultural theory ever written until today. You talked about the Vaseline tube as a sign of rejection of dominant culture, an object around which style is constructed. But Vaseline is not only an object but also a body technique, enabling certain sexual practices, opening somatic possibilities for penetration and production of pleasure. In your book, the body is treated almost as another object, being the function of a quiff not different to that of a scooter or a pair of boots. But how does the body relate to other objects in the production of style? Isn’t the body the living port where both political control and the production of style get hooked up? Could style be considered a cultural body prosthesis? Are there somatic limits to the production of style? Would you agree on describing gay, lesbian, queer, transgender and transsexual cultures as sexual and gender styles? Therefore, could your notion of style be expanded to deal with sexual production and body mutation? Could transgender and gender queer movements be thought as subcultural biotech-styles in tension with naturalized heterosexual gender styles? What would be the consequences of this move for political action?

speech.speaker: Lars Bang Larsen:
speech.p: I understand that you have recently been looking into the counterculture and psychedelic art of the 1960s. What made you engage with this field of research, and how does it connect to your seminal book on style, which mainly took punk as its critical object, and in this way located its historical framework a decade later? I am wondering what conflicts or overlaps there may be between a concept of style that is based on punk as a site of resistance, and a more utopian, countercultural visuality and behaviour – which, as the cliché has it, were ‘anti-style’.

speech.speaker: Brad Eberhard:
speech.p: You approach your multimedia lectures as performances. How did this develop? In your recent presentation on animal sounds in rockabilly music at the Hammer Museum in Los Angeles (March 2005), you described your intellectual process as ‘thinking through music’. I am curious about how you chose the topic and how you developed your ideas through it. Did it begin with certain songs? Performers? Or was did it have more to do with the chronology of your trilogy of lectures about American culture in the 20th century?

bio.title: Biographical note
bio.p: Dick Hebdige is Professor of Art Studio and Film & Media Studies at the University of California Santa Barbara. He is the author of Subculture The Meaning of Style (London: Methuen, 1979; London, New York. Routledge 1981), Cut’n’Mix. Culture, Identity and Caribbean Music (London: Routledge, 1987) and Hiding in the Light. On Images and Things (London. Routledge, 1988). He served from 1992–2001 as Dean of Critical Studies and Director of the Writing Program at California Institute of the Arts and from 2001–2008 as Director of the Interdisciplinary Humanities Center at the University of California Santa Barbara. He currently serves as the Univresity of California Institute for Research in the Arts Director of the Desert Studies Project.
